title: Mendelian randomization study of adiposity-related traits and risk of breast, ovarian, prostate, lung and colorectal cancer
author: Gao
author_address: Program in Genetic Epidemiology and Statistical Genetics, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, Boston, MA, USA,
hypothesis: Effect of birthweight, childhood and adult body mass index, and waist-hip ratio on the risks of breast, ovarian, prostate, colorectal and lung cancer
rationale: Adiposity traits have been associated with risk of many cancers in observational studies, but whether these associations are causal is unclear.
limitations_overall: Discuss several: MR assumptions, limits of summary level approach, limited power
limitations_pleiotropy: To test for and correct for bias due to pleiotropy where the InSIDE assumption holds, we performed Egger regression for all traits investigated
limitations_population_stratification: population stratification may be a source of confounding but the original studies saw little evidence for such bias and all have appropriately controlled for it.
limitations_statistical_power: Finally, the statistical power is limited by both the proportion of the adiposity risk factors explained by the genetic instruments, and the sample size in the cancer genetic association studies
notes: Repeated analysis after removing overlapping loci, same results

title: Effect of increased body mass index on risk of diagnosis or death from cancer
author: Gharahkhani
author_address: QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
hypothesis: Effect of BMI on overall cancer risk and cancer mortality
rationale: High BMI is strongly associated with increased risk of various cancers.
exposure_study: Puya Gharahkhani  2019 BMI White British adults both
exposure_pleiotropy: To assess this assumption, we repeated the analyses by removing a subset of SNPs that were associated with potential confounders. These were identified by having a Bonferroni-corrected P < 1×10-5 for 520 SNPs tested in nine traits; smoking (four traits), alcohol intake (two traits), coffee/tea consumption (two traits), and height (one trait). In addition, to test for the presence of directional pleiotropy, we used two approaches: (1) we created funnel plots for the MR estimates for all SNPs used as instrumental variable, where asymmetry in the funnel plots indicates directional pleiotropy; and (2) we used the MR Egger regression approach where a non-zero intercept indicates presence of directional pleiotropy.2
MR_sensitivity_method1: Re-ran analysis using subset of SNPs, having removed SNPs associated with potential confounders
MR_sensitivity_method_results: We repeated the analyses by removing a subset of SNPs that were associated with potential confounders. These were identified by having a Bonferroni-corrected P < 1×10-5 for 520 SNPs tested in nine traits; smoking (four traits), alcohol intake (two traits), coffee/tea consumption (two traits), and height (one trait). In addition, to test for the presence of directional pleiotropy.
limitations_overall: Did not investigate the causal effect of obesity as a dichotomous risk factor. MR model assumed a linear relationship between genetically predicted BMI with cancer risk and mortality. Did not investigate the effect of BMI on cancer mortality in prevalent and incident cancers, separately. Overall cancer phenotype may be rather hetero- geneous
limitations_population_stratification: Used a homogenous population with all the participants being of white-British ancestry
limitations_statistical_power: Statistical power was quite low for a conclusive interpretation of the non-significant individual cancer results

title: Genetically Predicted Body Mass Index and Breast Cancer Risk: Mendelian Randomization Analyses of Data from 145,000 Women of European Descent
author: Guo
author_address: Division of Epidemiology, Department of Medicine, Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center, Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, Nashville, Tennessee, United States of America
hypothesis: Effect of BMI on breast cancer
rationale: Observational epidemiological studies have shown that high body mass index (BMI) is associated with a reduced risk of breast cancer in premenopausal women but an increased risk in postmenopausal women. It is unclear whether this association is mediated through shared genetic or environmental factors.
outcome_definition: Defined in Breast Cancer Association Consortium (BCAC)
exposure_n_difference_reason: One-sample where they got exposure SNPs from external GWAS
exposure_independence: Selected independent SNPs, defined as r2 < 0.1
n_SNP_difference_reason: SNPs from Locke et al (77) were combined with SNPs associated with variation in BMI identified from the NHGRI-EBI Catalog of Published Genome-Wide Association Studies in August 2015
MR_sensitivity_method_results: In addition to pooled analysis also conducted meta-analysis, we estimated the risk of breast cancer associated with BMI-GS in each of the BCAC studies
replication_subsetting: Used summary statistics from the Discovery, Biology, and Risk of Inherited Variants in Breast Cancer (DRIVE) Project to look at BMI and breast cancer risk
limitations_overall: Our study has certain limitations. To date, GWAS-identified SNPs represent a small, but statistically significant, portion of the explained variance of observed BMI—approximately 2.7%
limitations_pleiotropy: some of the BMI-associated SNPs may be related to other traits. However, we were unable to evaluate these hypotheses in our study.
limitations_statistical_power: Using data from approximately 146,000 women involved in two large consortia, we provide strong evidence of an inverse association between genetically predicted BMI and breast cancer risk for both premenopausal and postmenopausal women

title: Mendelian randomization analysis using mixture models for robust and efficient estimation of causal effects
author: Qi
author_address: 12 Department of Biostatistics, Bloomberg School of Public Health, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD 21205, USA., Department of Oncology, School of Medicine, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD 21205, USA
hypothesis: Method: Effect of body mass index on coronary artery disease, breast cancer, and major depressive disorder
rationale: Method paper proposing a novel approach for robust and efficient MR analysis using large number of genetic instruments, based on a novel spike-detection algorithm under a normal-mixture model for underlying effect-size distributions.
outcome_study: Michailidou  2017 Breast Cancer  European and East Asian  female
limitations_overall: Method comparison paper using BMI as example. Only discussed method not the example

title:
Associations of obesity and circulating
 insulin and glucose with breast cancer risk:
 a Mendelian randomization analysis
author: Shu
author_address: Vanderbilt Epidemiology Center and Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center, Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, 2525 West End Avenue, 8th Floor, Nashville, TN 37203-1738, USA
hypothesis: Effect of adiposity measures on type 2 diabetes and breast cancer
rationale:
In addition to the established association between general obesity and
breast cancer risk, central obesity and circulating fasting insulin and glucose have been
linked to the development of this common malignancy. Findings from previous studies,
however, have been inconsistent, and the nature of the associations is unclear.
exposure_n_difference_reason: SNPs were selected from multiple studies by searching the National Human Genome Research Institute-European Bioinformatics Institute Catalogof Published Genome-Wide Association Studies and the literaturefor SNPs associated with the following traits: levels of2-h glucose (2hrGlu), fasting glucose (FG), fasting insulin(FI), BMI and waist-hip-ratio with adjustment of BMI(WHRadj BMI).
n_SNP_difference_reason: SNPs were selected from multiple studies by searching the National Human Genome Research Institute-European Bioinformatics Institute Catalogof Published Genome-Wide Association Studies and the literaturefor SNPs associated with the following traits: levels of2-h glucose (2hrGlu), fasting glucose (FG), fasting insulin(FI), BMI and waist-hip-ratio with adjustment of BMI(WHRadj BMI).
MR_sensitivity_method_results: Associations of wPRSs with breast cancer risk were evaluated separately in the iCOGs and OncoArray datasets by  treating these scores as continuous variables. A logistic regression was performed with age at interview/diagnosis, study site/country and PCs as covariates. The results were then combined using meta-analyses in METAL with a fixed effects model.
limitations_overall: Pleiotropy effect exist in obesity association studies; statistical power might be low because of low variance explained by IVs.
limitations_pleiotropy: Pleiotropy was found for the associations of obesity, but it is not likely that the observed associations can be primarily explained by pleiotropic effects.
limitations_statistical_power: Our ability to perform Mendelianrandomization analysis is limited by the genetic variants identified to date in GWAS, and the variance explained bythese genetic variants for some traits is small. We used 10 instruments in our main analysis, which could lead to false positive findings due to multiple comparisons. However, the associations reported in this study for 2-h glucose, fastinginsulin, BMI and WHRadj BMI were robust, reaching thestringent Bonferroni corrected significance level (P < 0.005).
